neutron_taas/services/taas/service_drive.message: introducing abstract methods this way breaks existing drivers. note that there are some out-of-tree drivers.

* it's assumed that versions of the same cycle are compatible. eg. taas train for networking-midonet train
* usually this kind of changes involve either 1. making changes on all relevant repos, or 2. making it optional at least for a while.
* the lack of pypi release is just a result of oversights/EBUSY.
* the lack of taas train has no reasons. usually i create release/branch manually after the corresponding neutron release. for train it hasn't happened yet.

thanks Takashi for the answer.
I think making these methods optional, i.e. not abstract first can help, but of course is not a guarantee that the relevant changes will ever happen in all the projects.

I suppose Takashi referenced these users of TaasBaseDriver http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=TaasBaseDriver&i=nope&files=&repos=

As I see it:
* tap-as-a-service is a library for these projects.

* I checked only midonet and bigswitch, so this is not a representative study:
** tap-as-a-service (and l2gw for example) is not in requirements.txt, and not anchored to a specific version.
** This can be really problematic if a change like the proposed one introduces new abstract APIs.

* As tap-as-a-service has releases (at least I see tags), these projects should use versions to make sure that their dependencies are not breaking anything.
** on pypi I see only 3.0.0 version, so it is a good question why there is no more releases.
** I can check why taas is missing train branch.

Takashi, as You have more experience with these networking projects, shall I ask your opinion?

swift/proxy/controllers/container.py.message: big advantage of using *this* condition to indicate "the top-level request to list objects w/i a sharded namespace" is that works both with root db's AND internal client requests directly to a sub-sharded .shards_a/c
if we agree on the following comment then we can rip out 'policy_key in resp.headers'

My reading on the history is that *all* versions of Swift that support sharding (and so would actually *be able* to return shard ranges) will include X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index in the response. In fact, all versions of Swift *since storage policies were introduced* should send it.

So yeah, I'd be fine with dropping the

 and policy_key in resp.headers

So long as we now resp can never be some other resp, like a 404 or 500 or something they maynot have the header.. but looking at the GETorHEAD method that call it, it has to have a 'X-Backend-Record-Type: shard' to ever be called, and if it has that header then it should be a proper resp and therefore have a 'X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'.

I see no harm in keeping it as it's a getekeeper just in case.. but it looks like it should never happen so I'm happy either way.

Note to future self: I'm satisfied the the header will always be in resp:

- if the response came from a backend then to have shard ranges it must be a new enough backend to also return a policy index

- if the response was composed from cached value in the proxy, then the presence of cached shard ranges is not sufficient - they may have come from a newer backend than the cached container info. However, this line is pertinent:

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/e40cf1ec561c78c8a02d40b581bf195939a6450a/swift/proxy/controllers/container.py#L146

i.e. we only fulfil a request from cache if the cached container info has a policy index

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
From the commit message, It appears that we are going to replace the tempest_test_whitelist with tempest_test_allowed without breaking the job?

The featureset variable tempest_test_whitelist can be overridden via featureset override by defining in the job definition.

But while renaming it in featureset it will break the job.

But during movement to tempest_test_allowed, if the job var is not found in allowed list then tempest_allowed_group will be used.

I think the commit message needs a little explanation.
Some like this:

```
Updating the logic to set the precedence of jobs and group.

Due to the fact that the variable tempest_test_whitelist is often found in the featureset and this one can't be ovewritten, In order to remove it[1], We are renaming it to tempest_allowed_group.

Since Job and group are mutually exclusive.
When the tempest_allow role[2] parses the allowed variables, It first set the preference to job  and if the job is not found, it will fallback to group.

So this way  So we can repalce the variable
tempest_test_whitelist on the featureset files without break the jobs.

Links:
[1]. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/+/792909

[2]. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/+/802484
```

manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/base.py.message: This change makes it such that the default share_v1/share_v2 clients are now using the admin user - that'd be incorrect. the reason for this class's existence was to be able to use the primary user for testing most things, and the admin user optionally.

Thanks for the wording.
Now it is certainly clearer what the purpose of the class is.

Why the default is admin user ? it depends on which client you're using.
Both classes initialize admin credential.
The clients are initialized in "setup_clients" methods and for each user there is a separated client.
for admin => "admin_shares_client" for primary => "shares_client".
Beyond that "BaseSharesMixedTest" class is used in many places within the admin test suite.

Ah, I see - I assumed we were initializing the "default share clients" (v1/v2) based on the class. However, it's based on the first value in the "credentials" list: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/540e74ac3da07cf62a00ab7976fb9382cf2e59a8/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/base.py#L165-L169

So, because the first value is "primary", we get the non-privileged user's credentials.I like this change then as a simplification. 

Can you expand the class's docstring so the next person doesn't get confused like me:

"""Base test case class for all Shares API tests with all user roles.


   Tests deriving from this class can use the primary project's clients 
   (self.shares_client, self.shares_v2_client) and the alt project user's
   clients (self.alt_shares_client, self.alt_shares_v2_client) to perform
   API calls and validations. Although admin clients are available for use,
   their use should be limited to performing bootstrapping (e.g., creating
   a share type, or resetting state of a resource, etc.). No API validation
   must be performed against admin APIs. Use BaseAdminTest as a base class
   for such tests.
"""
So it's not really accurate to say it's used for primary user and admin user is optional.

I think this paging logic could be a problem if the last item is the beginning of a long stretch of things I don't have access to see. For example, if I'm doing a list with a page size of 10, and then there's a stretch of 15 items I don't have access to via policy. When I list the second page, all of them will be filtered out of ns_list by policy, which means there will be nothing returned *and* nothing to provide a link to the third page to continue with items I *can* see.

I may have answered my own question here after looking at the API reference [0]. Documenting it here in case it's useful for anyone else.

Here is an example where the target built in the MetadefAPIPolicy constructor won't have a target that corresponds to the metadef namespace being created, but instead it will just have a project_id attribute that matches the project_id of the context, nooping the policy check.

I think that might only be a problem when the API accepts multiple ways of setting the project_id for a resource. For example, if you're allowed to set the project_id for a namespace in the body, and if that's not present then default to using the project_id from the user's context object (which comes from the token).

    "description": "A metadata definitions namespace for example use.",
    "visibility": "public",
    "protected": true,

  }
